Jeff, by the way, congrats on the quadruped paper! I hope it helps
others e=
volve ambulating creatures with HyperNEAT as well.  It really
helps to have=
 the example you have now provided that shows how such a
substrate might be=
 set up.

I answer your questions on the biped below:

--- In neat@yahoogro=
ups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Ken-
> 
> > We have actually=
 been running biped evolution experiments recently at
> > UCF because we wo=
uld like to use it as a test domain in the future as
> > well.  In our effo=
rts, we have learned a couple things that may answer
> 
> That is exciting =
that you are working on bipeds. I am anxious to see
your
> results. Since y=
ou mention it as a test bed, I am curious to hear
what you
> are comparing =
your results to. Is Tyler Streeter's work considered
the best
> EC has to o=
ffer? How about for CS in general? Do you have quantitative
> benchmarks yo=
u can use, such as speed, from another system?
> 
 
I think it's difficult =
to find a good benchmark.  There are some
publications citing successful bi=
ped walking, such as Reil and
Husbands, but no one seems to be able to repr=
oduce their results with
the same setup.  In fact, I have never heard of an=
yone reproducing
their results although I know several who have tried; I wo=
uld be
interested to hear from anyone who has.  There are some other works
=
that produced bipeds as well, though I don't know the citations
offhand.  B=
ut they usually involve some kind of hand-designed aspect
or a "hand of God=
," which means something that holds the biped up
while it is learning, kind=
 of like training wheels.  That makes
comparison with such systems kind of =
apples and oranges if you don't
apply such techniques.  And I think ideally=
 we'd like to be able to
just tell evolution to go and let it do its own th=
ing.

Given the anecdotal difficulty of the problem, for now I would
consid=
er it a success to get any biped to walk without any special
tricks.  I do =
not see the biped so much as a benchmark as I see it a
gateway to more inte=
resting domains.  If you can evolve a biped, then
you can probably evolve a=
 lot of other creatures and also make bipeds
that do increasingly interesti=
ng things.  It also validates a method's
ability to produce complex control=
lers.  

> That's cool that leaky integrators are working well for you. I
s=
hould point
> out that I did not try leaky integrators in my setup, so I do=
 not
know that
> they do worse in my setup. I was simply hypothesizing that=
 leaky
integrators
> were one thing that was obviously different between Pe=
ter's setup and my
> own, and therefore may have been part of the cause of =
the difference in
> results that we saw. I think it would be interesting to=
 try my setup
with
> Leaky Integrators. 
> 
> To get your oscillations, do =
you also need recurrence?
> 

Yes, recurrence is necessary to get oscillati=
ons with leaky
integrators, which brings up an interesting issue for HyperN=
EAT: The
substrate must include some sort of recurrence in its architecture=
.  I
don't think many aside from Peter have played with recurrent
substrate=
s.  Of course, it should be possible and interesting to try.

> > Second, t=
he model morphology is critical.  You cannot simply expect
> > any biped to=
 walk.  Great care is necessary to ensure that everything
> > about the mod=
el makes sense and is proportionate.
> 
> I agree. I'll be morphology makes=
 an even bigger difference in the biped
> domain, which is harder and more =
unstable. Out of curiosity, how are you
> tuning morphology? By hand? Via e=
volution?
> 

We've been optimizing morphology by hand, but I can imagine i=
t would
be interesting to do it with evolution as well.  There are a lot of=

possible ways that could be set up.  The reason we're doing it by hand
is =
so that we can get an intuitive understanding of the relationship
between b=
iped morphology and performance.

> A final question: if morphology is crit=
ical, how will you compare your
> results to others. Are you trying to use =
the exact same morphology
as other
> papers?
> 

Like I said, at the moment=
 our focus is not on comparison.  What we
want is a concrete understanding =
of the domain: What makes it hard,
what are the keys to making it work, wha=
t makes it most interesting,
etc.  Perhaps we will think about comparison l=
ater.  But I think at
the moment the interesting question is why so many ha=
ve trouble with
this problem.  Even Tyler Streeter only got his biped to wa=
lk a few
steps before falling.  We want to master the domain completely so =
that
in the future anyone can play with it easily and use it as a gateway
t=
o more interesting and complex control problems.

ken
